articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This ephemeris provides a guide to celestial observations for May 14-16, detailing the positions of Saturn and Mars in the evening sky after their oppositions, and the full Moon's recent passes and potential pale eclipse. It also notes a rough planetary alignment of Saturn, Mars, Earth, and Mercury during April and May, complemented by a sky map showing other planets and prominent stars.

articles.title: MAY SJAA CALENDAR OF EVENTS
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) May calendar, featuring various astronomical events like planetary oppositions, moon phases, and meteor showers, alongside club activities such as general meetings and star parties. It also reports on a historic $36 million bequest to the University of California for a new 400-inch telescope on Mauna Kea, details SJAA's fundraising success, and announces a presentation on Space Shuttle operations and an upcoming annular solar eclipse.

articles.title: Club Telescopes Available
articles.summary: The article announces the availability of club telescopes, including a 14" Dobsonian, 6" Newtonian, and 12" Dobsonian, for loan to interested members, with contact information for the custodians. Additionally, it provides an update that the telescopes at Lick Observatory sustained no damage after a recent earthquake, though realignment was necessary.

articles.title: Calico Observatory
articles.summary: Calico Observatory, located at 3508 Calico Ave, San Jose, Cal. 95124, provides its contact phone number as (408) 371-1307. This information was documented on April 22, 1984.

articles.title: Great Red Spot
articles.summary: This article provides a list of recommended observation times for viewing Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) during May, noting that Jupiter is an after-midnight object. The author encourages observers to submit reports, especially those using smaller instruments, detailing aperture, magnification, and observing conditions. It also suggests checking the Spot's position half an hour prior to the listed times to confirm its motion.

articles.title: DEEP SKY NOTES - MAY
articles.summary: This article provides deep sky observing notes for May, focusing on the galaxy-rich Virgo-Coma Berenices supercluster. It offers guidance on locating and observing several celestial objects, including galaxies M99, NGC 4565 (Needle Galaxy), M64 (Black Eye Galaxy), and globular clusters M53 and NGC 5053, with detailed personal observing reports using various telescopes. The author shares tips on dealing with the high density of galaxies and the scarcity of bright field stars in this region.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK OBSERVING SIGHT
articles.summary: This document outlines directions to the Fremont Peak observing site from South San Jose, detailing the route via US-101 S and CA-156 E. It includes map elements, distances, and mentions features like a camp-sight and a ranger's house, suggesting it is a dedicated location for astronomical observation or group events.

articles.title: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Challenger successfully repaired the Solar Maximum satellite, with plans for future in-orbit servicing of spacecraft like Landsat 4 and Palapa B-2 also discussed. However, failures in the PAM upper stage motors are causing widespread launch delays for multiple communication and navigation satellites, impacting upcoming shuttle missions and other booster launches. These technical issues are also affecting the next shuttle flight, 41-D, involving the new orbiter Discovery.

articles.title: SPACE UPDATE(cont'd)
articles.summary: This article provides an update on near-term space activities, detailing upcoming NASA and Ariane rocket launches in May and July for various communications satellites. It also covers a recent visit by Indian and Soviet cosmonauts to the Salyut-7 space station, and plans for future Space Shuttle missions in 1985 to include French and potentially Chinese astronauts, highlighting international cooperation in space.

articles.title: THE MOSTLY CLOUDY MESSIER MARATHON        84-11-84
articles.summary: The 1984 Messier Marathon weekend was largely clouded out, preventing a successful group observation. Despite this, the author, Don Machholz, independently observed 109 Messier objects on March 19th from Loma Prieta, even with a bright moon. The article concludes by listing optimal dates for future Messier Marathons in 1984 (July, October) and 1985 (March 15-17).

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS                                04-18-84
articles.summary: This article, dated April 18, 1984, provides updates on several comets. It announces the recent discovery of faint Comet Russell 4 and notes that Comets Crommelin and Hartley-IRAS have faded. The author also mentions checking on Comet Halley as it approaches the inner solar system, providing its May 1984 positional data, and briefly recalls two earth-grazing comets from the previous year.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: The article details the discovery circumstances of two comets from 1983, Comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock and Comet Sugano-Saigusa-Fujikawa, both of which made close approaches to Earth. It explores why their discoveries were delayed despite being potentially observable earlier, discussing factors like rapid brightening, observer focus, and challenging viewing conditions. The piece also speculates on alternative scenarios for their detection based on orbital variations.

articles.title: A "Road Map" for the Commuting Astronomer
articles.summary: This article, "A 'Road Map' for the Commuting Astronomer," addresses the common problem amateur astronomers face with declining backyard observing conditions. Author Don Machholz explains the need to seek remote observing sites due to issues like light pollution, unsteady atmospheric 'seeing,' and obstructed horizons. He offers initial tips for optimizing backyard observations before detailing the specific site characteristics (uniform terrain for steady seeing, open plains/ridges for low horizons, and remote locations for dark skies) that resolve these challenges for the "commuting astronomer."

articles.title: SHOWROOM N
articles.summary: This document is an advertisement for TAU MODULAR DISPLAY GARAGE in San Mateo, featuring sales and factory rebates on a variety of astronomical equipment. It offers discounted prices on Celestron and Meade telescopes and accessories, with specific models like the TeleStar 60mm and Celestron C-90DE highlighted. All listed sales and rebates were valid through December 31, 1998.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document is an application and renewal form for SJAA membership, detailing fields for personal contact information and areas of interest. It outlines various membership tiers, including general, "MEMBERSHIP ONLY*", and junior options, each with associated annual fees. Instructions for submitting renewals, including remittance details and the treasurer's contact information (Bob Fitzgerald in Milpitas, CA), are also provided.

articles.title: LUMICON
articles.summary: Lumicon, a company emphasizing "High Quality in Astronomy," is conducting a stock clearance sale. The sale offers various types of filters, including Star, Comet, and Nebula filters, along with other Lumicon and Galaxy products.

articles.title: WORLD CENTER FOR
articles.summary: This document advertises a "WORLD CENTER FOR DEEP-SKY FILTERS" located at 2111 Research Dr #5C, Diamond, CA 91765. It specifically mentions selling LUMICON filters and provides a contact phone number. The text appears to be a business advertisement for astronomical observing equipment.

articles.title: ATA
articles.summary: ATA, located in Oakland, CA, specializes in aluminum castings and offers primary and secondary mirrors with a unique ribbon monouda over-coating for microbes. They provide a price list for various mirror sizes (e.g., 4" to 16"), which includes the primary mirror, secondary mirror, postage, and insurance, with mirrors being shipped to Chico for coating.

articles.title: Everything For Astronomers
articles.summary: This document is an advertisement for an astronomy equipment retailer located in San Jose, CA. It highlights a range of optical solutions and instruments for astronomers, featuring brands such as Dynamax, Odyssey, Swift Instruments, Lumicon, Accurack, and Celestron, along with binoculars. The ad invites customers to visit their showroom, request a catalog, and emphasizes their specialization in optical products.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document is an application and renewal form for membership with the SJAA. It outlines various membership options and their associated fees, including standard and junior rates. The form instructs applicants to fill in personal details and send the form and payment to the designated treasurer, Bob Fitzgerald.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document is an 'EPHEMERIS' for May 1984, likely a newsletter or publication from the SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association), judging by the address. It is marked as 'TIME VALUE â€” DATED NEWS MATERIAL' and distributed via bulk mail.
